subject: Physics
expanded_description: Comprehensive introduction to torque as the rotational analog of force. Covers torque calculation, the cross product relationship, lever arms, and applications to rotational equilibrium and dynamics.
learning_objectives: Define torque and calculate it using multiple methods
Apply the right-hand rule for torque direction
Apply torque concepts to real-world mechanical systems

core_concept.principle: Torque ($\tau$) is the rotational analog of force, causing angular acceleration. It is defined as $\tau = rF\sin\theta = r_{\perp}F = Fr_{\perp}$, where r is the position vector, F is the force, θ is the angle between them, and $r_{\perp}$ is the lever arm (perpendicular distance from pivot to force line).
core_concept.explanation: Torque depends on both the magnitude of force and where/how it's applied. The same force can produce different torques depending on the point of application and direction relative to the pivot.

image.alt: Diagram showing torque components and lever arm
image.caption: Torque depends on force magnitude, application point, and force direction relative to pivot

sections.introduction: Torque quantifies the effectiveness of a force at causing rotation. Understanding the three equivalent ways to calculate torque provides flexibility in solving different types of problems.

image.alt: Three methods for calculating torque illustrated
image.caption: Torque can be calculated using force and lever arm, force components, or cross product

key_concept.definition: Torque can be calculated three ways: (1) $\tau = rF\sin\theta$ using the angle between position and force vectors, (2) $\tau = r_{\perp}F$ using the perpendicular lever arm, (3) $\tau = Fr_{\perp}$ using the force component perpendicular to position vector. The SI unit is Newton-meter (N·m).
key_concept.context: These equivalent formulations allow choosing the most convenient approach based on given information in a problem.

image.alt: Visual comparison of three torque calculation methods
image.caption: Three equivalent approaches to torque calculation

classifications.value: Different mathematical methods for computing torque
classifications.behavior: Each method emphasizes different geometric relationships but yields identical results

examples.explanation: τ = F × (perpendicular distance from pivot to force line) - most intuitive approach

image.alt: Lever arm distance shown perpendicular to force
image.caption: Lever arm is the perpendicular distance from pivot to force line

examples.explanation: τ = r × (force component perpendicular to r) - useful when angles are known

image.alt: Force resolved into perpendicular and parallel components
image.caption: Only the force component perpendicular to r produces torque

classifications.note: Forces applied directly toward or away from the pivot (θ = 0° or 180°) produce zero torque

principles.statement: The direction of torque is given by the right-hand rule: point fingers in direction of r, curl toward F, thumb gives torque direction. Counterclockwise torques are typically positive, clockwise negative.
principles.application: This determines whether torques cause clockwise or counterclockwise rotation and is essential for analyzing systems with multiple torques
principles.example: A force applied to the right side of a wheel pointing upward produces counterclockwise rotation
principles.analogy: Like turning a screw - right-hand rule gives the direction the screw would drive

image.alt: Right-hand rule demonstration for torque direction
image.caption: Right-hand rule determines torque direction as a vector perpendicular to the r-F plane

worked_examples.title: Basic Torque Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A 20 N force is applied to a wrench 0.3 m from a bolt. If the force is perpendicular to the wrench, find the torque. If applied at 30° to the wrench, find the new torque.

step_by_step.explanation: At 30°, lever arm = rsinθ = 0.3 × 0.5 = 0.15 m, τ = F × lever arm = 20 × 0.15 = 3 N·m

worked_examples.concept_applied: Basic torque calculation with different angles

image.alt: Wrench with force applied at different angles
image.caption: Torque decreases as force becomes less perpendicular to wrench

worked_examples.title: Multiple Torque Calculation Methods
worked_examples.problem: A force F = 50 N is applied at point (3, 4) m from pivot at origin. The force vector is (30, 40) N. Calculate torque using all three methods.

step_by_step.explanation: r = 5 m, F = 50 N, find angle between r and F vectors
Find perpendicular distance from pivot to force line
Find force component perpendicular to r

worked_examples.final_answer: All methods give τ = 0 N·m (force directed through pivot)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Multiple torque calculation methods demonstrating equivalence

image.alt: Force directed through pivot produces zero torque
image.caption: Forces directed through the pivot point produce zero torque

sections.introduction: Rotational equilibrium occurs when the net torque on a system is zero, preventing angular acceleration. This principle is fundamental to analyzing seesaws, levers, bridges, and other static structures.

image.alt: Various systems in rotational equilibrium
image.caption: Rotational equilibrium requires net torque = 0 for no rotation

key_concept.definition: For rotational equilibrium: $\sum\tau = 0$. This means the sum of all clockwise torques equals the sum of all counterclockwise torques about any pivot point. Combined with translational equilibrium ($\sum F = 0$), this completely describes static systems.
key_concept.context: This condition ensures objects don't start rotating and is used to design balanced structures and calculate unknown forces.

image.alt: Mathematical conditions for complete equilibrium
image.caption: Complete equilibrium requires both net force = 0 and net torque = 0

classifications.value: Different scenarios requiring rotational equilibrium analysis
characteristics: Objects on pivots with multiple forces
classifications.behavior: The choice of pivot point can simplify calculations by eliminating unknown forces from torque equations

examples.explanation: Two masses on a pivot: m₁g × r₁ = m₂g × r₂ for balance

image.alt: Balanced seesaw with different masses
image.caption: Seesaw balances when torques from each side are equal

examples.explanation: Beam supported at one end with load: support force creates counter-torque to load torque

image.alt: Beam supported at one end with load
image.caption: Support force provides torque to balance load torque

classifications.note: You can choose any point as the pivot for torque calculations - smart choice simplifies the math

principles.statement: When solving equilibrium problems, choose the pivot point at the location of an unknown force. This eliminates that force from the torque equation, simplifying the solution.
principles.application: This strategy reduces the number of variables in torque equations, making systems easier to solve
principles.example: For a ladder leaning on a wall, choose the pivot at the base to eliminate the unknown horizontal force from the wall
principles.analogy: Like solving a system of equations by eliminating variables - smart pivot choice does this automatically

image.alt: Choosing pivot at unknown force location
image.caption: Strategic pivot selection eliminates unknown forces from torque equations

worked_examples.title: Seesaw Equilibrium
worked_examples.problem: A 30 kg child sits 2 m from the pivot of a seesaw. Where should a 40 kg child sit to balance?
worked_examples.final_answer: 40 kg child should sit 1.5 m from pivot
worked_examples.concept_applied: Simple lever equilibrium with two masses

image.alt: Seesaw with children at different positions
image.caption: Heavier child must sit closer to pivot for balance

worked_examples.title: Beam with Multiple Forces
worked_examples.problem: A 4 m beam weighing 200 N is supported at both ends. A 500 N load is placed 1 m from left end. Find the support forces.

step_by_step.explanation: This eliminates F_left from torque equation
Beam weight at center: 200 × 2 = 400 N·m clockwise, Load: 500 × 1 = 500 N·m clockwise, Right support: F_right × 4 counterclockwise

worked_examples.final_answer: Left support = 475 N, Right support = 225 N
worked_examples.concept_applied: Rotational and translational equilibrium with distributed load

image.alt: Beam with weight and load supported at both ends
image.caption: Support forces determined by both torque and force equilibrium

sections.introduction: Torque causes angular acceleration according to the rotational analog of Newton's second law. This relationship connects torque to rotational motion and allows analysis of rotating systems under net torque.

image.alt: Rotating systems with net torque causing angular acceleration
image.caption: Net torque causes angular acceleration in rotating systems

key_concept.definition: Newton's second law for rotation: $\sum\tau = I\alpha$, where I is moment of inertia and α is angular acceleration. This is the rotational analog of $\sum F = ma$. The work done by torque is $W = \tau\Delta\theta$, and power is $P = \tau\omega$.
key_concept.context: This fundamental relationship allows prediction of rotational motion given applied torques, similar to how F=ma predicts linear motion.

image.alt: Rotational analog of Newton's second law
image.caption: Net torque equals moment of inertia times angular acceleration

classifications.value: Systems where torque causes angular acceleration
classifications.behavior: The angular acceleration is inversely proportional to moment of inertia for given torque

examples.explanation: Tension differences create net torque on pulley: $\tau_{net} = (T_2 - T_1)r = I\alpha$

image.alt: Pulley with different tensions causing rotation
image.caption: Unequal tensions create net torque causing pulley rotation

examples.explanation: Friction or applied forces create torque that causes both linear and angular acceleration

image.alt: Object rolling with acceleration
image.caption: Applied forces create torques that affect both translation and rotation

classifications.note: For objects rotating about fixed axes, only torque components parallel to the axis affect rotation

principles.statement: The angular acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net torque and inversely proportional to the moment of inertia: $\alpha = \frac{\sum\tau}{I}$. This means objects with larger I require more torque for the same angular acceleration.
principles.application: This explains why objects with mass distributed farther from the axis are harder to start or stop rotating
principles.example: A solid disk and a hoop with same mass and radius - the hoop has larger I and requires more torque for same angular acceleration
principles.analogy: Like pushing different masses - heavier objects accelerate less for the same force

image.alt: Relationship between torque, moment of inertia, and angular acceleration
image.caption: Angular acceleration depends on both net torque and moment of inertia

worked_examples.problem: A solid disk (I = ½MR²) of mass 10 kg and radius 0.5 m has a constant torque of 15 N·m applied. Find the angular acceleration.

step_by_step.step: Apply Newton's second law for rotation

worked_examples.title: Atwood Machine with Rotating Pulley
worked_examples.problem: An Atwood machine has masses 3 kg and 5 kg connected over a pulley (I = 0.2 kg·m², R = 0.1 m). Find the acceleration of masses and pulley angular acceleration.

step_by_step.explanation: τ_net = (T₁ - T₂)R = Iα, and a = Rα
Substitute and solve for a and α

worked_examples.final_answer: Linear acceleration = 2.41 m/s², Angular acceleration = 24.1 rad/s²

image.caption: Pulley rotation affects the acceleration of the masses

common_misconceptions: Thinking torque is the same as force
Thinking larger always forces produce larger torques
Assuming pivot must be at physical center
real_world_applications: Wrenches and tools for turning bolts
summary: Torque (τ) is the rotational analog of force, calculated as τ = rFsinθ = r⊥F = Fr⊥. It depends on force magnitude, application point, and direction relative to pivot. The right-hand rule determines torque direction. For rotational equilibrium, Στ = 0. For rotational dynamics, Στ = Iα (Newton's second law for rotation). Key principles: forces through pivot produce zero torque, strategic pivot selection simplifies equilibrium problems, and torque causes angular acceleration proportional to net torque and inversely proportional to moment of inertia. Torque units are Newton-meters (N·m), distinct from Joules despite same units, as torque is a vector (pseudovector) while energy is a scalar.
